title: 110_hr3548
content: The "Plain Language in Government Communications Act of 2008" aims to improve the Federal Government's communication effectiveness by promoting clear and understandable language. It defines "plain language" as language that is clear, concise, well-organized, and easily understood by the intended audience. Federal agencies are responsible for implementing these communication practices. The "Plain Language in Government Communications Act of 2008" requires federal agencies to use plain language in new documents within one year of enactment. Agencies can use plain language in revised documents and must use English when appropriate. Agencies can follow guidance from the Plain English Handbook or Federal Plain Language Guidelines. The "Plain Language in Government Communications Act of 2008" mandates the use of plain language by federal agencies in new documents within a year of enactment. It allows the use of plain language in revised documents and requires the use of English when necessary. The Act also includes provisions to protect the use of languages other than English and Native Alaskan or Native American languages. The "Plain Language in Government Communications Act of 2008" requires federal agencies to use plain language in documents related to obtaining benefits, filing taxes, or providing services. Agencies should aim to use plain language whenever possible. The Act also includes incorporating Comptroller General recommendations for specific agencies like the Federal Aviation Administration. The Act mandates federal agencies to use plain language in documents related to benefits, taxes, and services. Agencies must incorporate Comptroller General recommendations, with reports to committees on their implementation. The Act requires federal agencies to use plain language in documents related to benefits, taxes, and services. Agencies must incorporate Comptroller General recommendations into the Plain English Handbook. Reports on the implementation of these recommendations must be submitted to specific committees within six months. SEC. 5. REPORTS TO CONGRESS. Within six months of this Act's enactment, each agency must submit a report to specified congressional committees outlining their plans to comply with the Act's requirements, including communicating with employees, training in plain language writing, meeting deadlines, ensuring ongoing compliance, appointing a senior official for implementation, and using plain language in regulations. Annual and other reports are also required. The agency must submit annual reports to congressional committees on compliance with the Act and efforts to meet specified objectives. The Comptroller General will evaluate existing guidance on writing within six months of the Act's enactment. The General will evaluate existing guidance on writing in plain language and provide recommendations on plain language guidelines and best practices to relevant committees. The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 14, 2008.
